selected_quotes: RT DrBrianHart RT sanli Cavity-Assisted Manipulation of Freely Rotating Silicon Nanorods in High Vacuum #physics

citation.abstract: Optical control of nanoscale objects has recently developed into a thriving field of research with far-reaching promises for precision measurements, fundamental quantum physics and studies on single-particle thermodynamics. Here, we demonstrate the op- tical manipulation of silicon nanorods in high vacuum. Initially, we sculpture these particles into a silicon substrate with a tailored geometry to facilitate their launch into high vacuum by laser-induced mechanical cleavage. We manipulate and trace their center-of-mass and rotational motion through the interaction with an intense intra- cavity field. Our experiments show that the anisotropy of the nanorotors leads to optical forces which are three times stronger than on silicon nanospheres of the same mass. The optical torque experienced by the spinning rods will enable cooling of the rotational motion and torsional opto-mechanics in a dissipation-free environment.
citation.title: Cavity-Assisted Manipulation of Freely Rotating Silicon Nanorods in High Vacuum

author.name: Sanli Faez
author.description: Assistant professor, experimental physics, Utrecht University. Pro open-science and more transparency in academia. Allergic to hypocrisy.

author.name: Dr. Brian Hart
author.description: Astrophysicist and former Soldier interested in issues surrounding space, policy, and military technology applications. RTs and mentions don't mean endorsement.

news.title: Nanorotoren haben den Dreh raus
news.summary: Einem internationalen Team, bestehend aus ForscherInnen der Uni Wien, der Tel Aviv University und der Uni Duisburg-Essen, ist es erstmals gelungen, Nanostäbchen zu präparieren, mittels Laserlicht ins Vakuum zu heben, zu beeinflussen und zu verstehen.

news.title: Nano-Rotoren haben den Dreh raus
news.summary: Laserlicht misst und manipuliert die Bewegung von Nano-Stäbchen im Vakuum.
